DOC.HEAD: 250 to 350 May Die on Roads Over New Year's Weekend
DOC.TEXT: The National Safety Council estimates as many as 350 people may be killed in traffic accidents over the four-day New Year's holiday, which begins this evening. In addition, the Chicago-based council predicts that some 12,000 to 16,000 people may suffer disabling injuries in accidents on the nation's streets and highways. The council bases its estimates on data from previous years, seasonal weather conditions and national driving safety trends. It says 317 people died in car accidents during the New Year's holiday weekend last year. The official counting period begins at 6 p.m. EST today and runs though 11:59 p.m. Monday, closing at midnight in each time zone. Over this year's four-day Christmas holiday, 353 people died _ fewer than the 386 traffic fatalities reported in 1988. The safety council had estimated that between 320 and 420 people would die this year. The council said that alcohol _ a factor in more than half of all traffic fatalities _ poses a particular threat during the New Year's weekend, when many people attend holiday parties.
